From: "Mattias Fagerlund" <mattias@...>
Subject: Re: [neat] Re: Machine Learning and the Long View of AI
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=29390171; y=UNqxRxG_YG_h06sBxTDoR4gTpN4d4t9QqaCwCZNgmwarvyYWOASRe3rFiXQ
X-Yahoo-Profile: mattias_fagerlund

Hi guys!

Ken, you're saying that NE will eventually be able to do what one might
call symbolic reasoning? I can't wrap my head around that (a failing on my
part), any papers I should read that broaches the subject? Clearly, our
brain which does symbolic reasoning can handle it, so NE should be able to
do the same, but how to represent it with input, output and hidden nodes,
that's a little beyond me at the moment.

One practical problem I have with HyperNEAT is that we're back to deciding
the number of hidden node layers, and the number of nodes in each layer
for the phenotype. Any thoughts on how to handle that gracefully? A brute
force solution would simply be to provide each genotype with some kind of
evolvable descriptor that would determine the hidden nodes. But maybe that
could be represented within the genotype instead?

One very interesting experiment I'd like to see done (or do myself); if
the genotype decides the hidden nodes, can HyperNEAT successfully cross
two genotypes which different hidden node targets? It should be possible,
consider humans with our 46 chromosomes. There must have been a point
where one person had say 44 chromosomes but doubled up on one of them,
ending up with 46. Then that person mated with another person with the
usual 44 chromosomes, and successfully so. The reason it worked at all is
probably because the chomosomes were very similar, or even identical,
making the evolutionary landscape _fairly_ even when it comes to
chromosome duplications (99.9999...% of all chromosome duplications must
have resulted in abortion or sterility, but still).

Since HyperNEAT uses continuous functions to describe the connection
weights, that could possibly imply that the same evenness. It's impossible
to know without testing, but if we could mate one individual with one
hidden layer with another individual with two hidden layers and get viable
offspring (preferably stronger), that would be spectacular. Well, I would
think so anyway ;)

As for the 0.2 weight threshold being arbitrary, sure it's arbitrary, but
it's the landscape that evolution works with, it's as arbitrary as g
(gravity)=9.81, if g would have been say 5, animals would have been
different but no less successfull. Thus using a weight threshold of
0.1-0.3 would probably not change the results significantly - another
interesting experiment though. Where are the limits for the threshold? Too
close to 0 and the number of connections will explode. To close to 1 and
sigmoid nodes will have a hard time generating connections, and their
connection weight resolution would be seriously compromised.

with regards,
mattias
